text: Applies a billowy cloud like displacement noise to a fog volume.

Adds a noise displacement pattern to a volume field in order to create a billowy cloud like appearance. Various noise shaping options are available as well as masking controls. This is ideal for modeling large cumulus clouds, while the
is used to add wispy details to the cloud.
When this checkbox turned on, use the blend between the original input volume (given by

) and to modified volume by this node.
    Setting this value to
means that this node will not have an effect on the input volume. Optionally, you can provide a mask volume (given by
) to mask specific regions in the volume field.
Negates the fog volume mask from the second input, if any.

Controls the number of displacement iterations. Using a single iteration is generally not enough to create pleasing billowy details. However, doing more than one iteration will slow down the cooking process. When this is turned on, use the
tab to vary the billowy properties for each iteration for a more visually pleasing results.
When the checkbox is on, overwrites the visualization for the volume.
Controls how to shade the volume. When generating cloud patterns, use
to see all the finer details and
to display clouds in a more realistic manner.
Uses ambient shadowing to display the volume.
Reverses the ambient shadowing for volumes which can be used to give a more realistic cloud look with internal scattering.

Fixed multiplier on the density field to control how opaque the volume is.
    If you are using a larger scene scale, you may need a smaller density scale.

Fog density is density per unit length, and is independent of the 
        resolution. So the same sized box, at 100 or 10 divisions, should be the
        same opacity. This means very small boxes will become transparent,
        especially if HDR rendering isn’t on. You can enable HDR rendering on
        the

format to at least 16-bit for 3D textures
        can also help resolve low-density volumes. These settings can be found
        under the
Determines the intensity of self shadows from ambient light sources. The final amount of self-shadowing from these lights is controlled by the product of
. The video demonstrates the value increasing from 0 to 1.
Turning off this checkbox does not disable ambient shadowing. Instead, it keeps this property of the geometry unchanged. If no
controls the default amount of self-shadowing from ambient lights.
The default headlight is treated as an ambient source by fog volumes.

Color of smoke that’s receiving direct light from an ambient light source.
    The default white setting indicates that areas exposed to external lights
    are bright. You can set this darker than

to achieve a
    more cloud-like look, where areas deeper within the cloud experience more
    light scattering and thus appear brighter.

must be
    enabled to control this parameter.

Color of smoke that’s not receiving any light from an ambient light source.
    The default black setting indicates that areas occluded from light are dark.
    You can set this brighter than

to achieve a more
    cloud-like appearance, where areas deeper within the cloud (that is, those
    occluded from outside light) are more luminous due to a greater degree of
    internal scattering.

must be enabled to control this
    parameter.
These parameters control the global billowy noise pattern. When
is turned on, these values will only apply on the first iteration, while the
tab controls the rate of change in the values for each iteration.
The type of noise to generate. Different algorithms give noise with different characteristics.
The default. A faster and more interesting variant of Perlin noise.
Sparse Convolution noise is similar to Worley noise. Does not have artifacts at grid points.
Produces a bumpy output. Named for its alleged resemblance to alligator skin.
A noise where the visual details are the same size.
A noise that’s stable over time, like a rotated Perlin noise, useful to create noise that seems to swirl and flow smoothly across time. Use the
parameter below to control the rotation.
A noise similar to Perlin but the noise lattice is on a tetrahedral mesh rather than a grid.  This can avoid the grid patterns often visible in Perlin noise.
Produces cellular features similar to plant cells, ocean waves, honeycombs, cratered landscapes, and so on.
A variant of Worley noise that produces blunted and cornered features.
A variant of Worley F1 noise that uses Manhattan distance calculation. Useful when you want unusual-looking noise.
A variant of Worley F2-F1 noise that uses Manhattan distance calculation. Useful when you want unusual-looking noise.
A variant of Worley F1 noise that uses Chebyshev distance calculation. Useful when you want unusual-looking noise.
A variant of Worley F2-F1 noise that uses Chebyshev distance calculation. Useful when you want unusual-looking noise.
Generates perlin noise based cloud pattern influenced by the
Generates simplex noise based cloud pattern influenced by the
parameter. Simplex noise similar to Perlin, but the noise lattice is on a tetrahedral mesh rather than a grid.  This can avoid the grid patterns often visible in Perlin noise.
Generates fast simplex noise based cloud pattern influenced by the
parameter. This simplex noise function uses a different lattice structure and a cheaper accumulation method.
Controls the effect of the distortion. Large values will create larger billowy details in the pattern, but might create unrealistic looking cloud patterns.
Uniform scale of elements in the distortion noise. This scale is relative to
, which controls the overall pattern size.
Offset within the evaluated noise field (added to each axis). If you have the general noise effect you want, but want to get a different set of values for a different look, try changing the offset.
When turned on, a worley noise is combined with the noise pattern (specified by

) to give puffy cloud noise.
    Enabling this, will largely diminish the distortion effect (specified by
Noise pattern with added worley noise:
Controls the amount of mixing between the noise pattern (specified by
) and the worley noise. A value of
means no worley noise is applied to the noise pattern.
Controls how fast the edges of the noise pattern turn to zero. The larger the value, the more the edges are eroded creating smaller and smaller cloud patches.
parameter that effects the worley noise pattern.
This value controls how much the medium grey (noise values around
Controls how much the medium greys (noise values around
) are pulled together, while values around
are pulled apart. The value of
Controls the overall gamma of the generated noise. Values less than

will darken the noise, increasing the range of values in originally bright areas.
    Conversely, values greater than
will stretch out the range of values for originally dark areas, which will increase the overall brightness of the noise.
This value expands or shrinks the overall range of tonal values. Particularly, each noise value is pushed towards (if
Shifts the internal noise pattern range (roughly

) to displace the volume in the opposite direction of the surface normal as well.
    A value of
is larger than zero, this will set any negative noise value back to zero. Use this to create a displacement pattern that has areas without any displacement.
The fractal controls let you add additional fractal noise on top of the output of the basic noise type.
Does not add any additional noise on top of the basic noise.
Adds pseudo-random noise on top of the basic output.
but dampens the noise in the valleys, which can be useful for generating mountainous terrain.
Like terrain, but with more sharpness in the valleys.
The following parameters are available when Fractal type is anything except
The number of iterations of distortion to add to the output of the basic noise. The more iterations you add, the more

the output. Note that the output may have fewer octaves than this parameter (that is, increasing the parameter will eventually stop adding detail), because the node eventually stops when there’s no more room to add more detail in the output.
The frequency increment between iterations of fractal noise added to the basic output. Note that you can use a negative value.
The scale increment between iterations of fractal noise added to the basic output. The higher the value the larger the
added to the output. You can use a negative value for roughness.
Controls how much the noise is distorted in the direction of decreasing noise values if
, and in the direction of increasing noise values if
. When worley details are added to the noise pattern, the effect of distortion are largely diminished.
How much to stretch the noise in each direction. The advantage of using this instead of
is that it preserves some details unstretched, making the stretched noise pattern more natural looking.
Warps the generated noise such that the noise pattern is bending or hanging towards the given droop direction.
Noise pattern without (left) and with droop applied (right):
The direction in which the noise is warped.
Applies additional noise offset to the main noise to create finer details.
Controls the effect of the advection, large values will advect the noise more. This is a multiplier on the noise amplitude (given by
Uniform scale of elements in the noise. This is a multiplier on the noise element size (given by

Offset within the evaluated advection noise field (added to each axis). If you have the general noise effect you want, but want to get a different set of values for a different look, try changing the offset.
The number of iterations of distortion to add to the output of the basic noise. The more iterations you add, the more

the output. Note that the output may have fewer octaves than this parameter (that is, increasing the parameter will eventually stop adding detail), because the node eventually stops when there’s no more room to add more detail in the output.
The scale increment between iterations of fractal noise added to the basic output. The higher the value the larger the
added to the output. You can use a negative value for roughness.
These many numbers of noise patterns are generated in one iteration; each with different noise offset. Increasing this value will generate somewhat more filled and larger displacement noise.

Controls how the internal billowy noise is sampled based on position, greatly effecting the look of the displacement.
    The value of

means that the noise is sampled according to the closest point on the surface defined by the signed distance field of the incoming volume.
    Just as with displacing a geometry along its normal, the generated peaks have no detail along the axis of displacement. This visual drawback can be eliminated by enabling multiple billowy noise iterations (given by
means that the noise is sampled using the world position of each voxel. While this method applies displacement in all directions, by increasing the noise amplitude (given by
), this method can very easily lead to numerous isolated fog pieces around the main cloud.
When turned on, the displacement will decrease based on the surface normal direction and the up vector.
User specified up vector for noise falloff.
When this is turned on and multiple iterations are set (given by
), this will use the accumulated noise pattern in each iteration as a scalar on noise amplitude of the next iteration.

To apply noise displacement to the incoming volume, the active area must be expanded. The expansion amount is automatically calculated based on the given settings, and this value is a multiplier on top of that value. If you notice artifacts in the generated volume, the displacement amount is probably larger than expansion distance, in which case increase this number to create a larger active region.
When this is turned on, it resamples the incoming volume in each iteration. This parameter is useful when multiple iterations are set (given by
) to increase the number of voxels in the volume with each iteration (given by the

tab).
    It is rather common first to use a low-resolution incoming volume for testing. However, when you switch the input volume for a higher resolution version, the displacement features might look visually different. To preserve the features, leave the incoming resolution the same while this parameter and multiple iterations are enabled.

To find the normals of the incoming volume, the volume has to be converted to a signed distance field volume. When this is turned on, a lower resolution volume is used than generated the SDF field, speeding up the conversion process. Increased values will generate lower resolution SDF field.
are turned on, these parameters control the rate of change in the corresponding parameter values for each iteration.
and this parameter are turned on, this controls the amplitude reduction for each iteration.
, the table shows the final amplitude value for each iteration:
and this parameter are turned on, this controls the element size reduction for each iteration.
and this parameter are turned on, this controls the reduction in the number of noises for each iteration.
and this parameter are turned on, this controls the worley blend reduction for each iteration.
and this parameter are turned on, this controls the worley erosion reduction for each iteration.
and this parameter are turned on, this controls the bias reduction for each iteration.
and this parameter are turned on, this controls the gain reduction for each iteration.
and this parameter are turned on, this controls the gamma reduction for each iteration.
and this parameter are turned on, this controls the contrast reduction for each iteration.
and this parameter are turned on, this controls the number of octave reductions for each iteration.
and this parameter are turned on, this controls the roughness reductions for each iteration.
and this parameter are turned on, this controls the distortion reductions for each iteration.
and this parameter are turned on, this controls the droop reductions for each iteration.
and this parameter are turned on, this controls the stretch reductions for each iteration.
and this parameter are turned on, this controls the rest position bias reductions for each iteration.
and this parameter are turned on, this controls the up vector bias reductions for each iteration.
and this parameter are turned on, this controls the voxel size reductions for each iteration.
The name of the volume to be used as density for generating the billowy noise. Usually you should leave it as
The name of the volume to be used as mask generating the billowy noise. Usually you should leave it as

title: Cloud Billowy Noise
summary: Applies a billowy cloud like displacement noise to a fog volume.
